comments.commentBody: It's a bit more like the crude oil train that stopped for the night above Lac-Mégantic, Québec.  The brakes didn't quite work and the train began to move very slowly, then a bit faster.  It eventually rolled, pretty fast, into town, setting it on fire.  Climate change hasn't "already" happened.  We're merely at the start of a long, nasty runaway situation.  The more carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases we add to the atmosphere, the longer and faster change will continue.

@Skeptical: We may be Across the Pond, but even we Americans have heard about the difficulty so many Brits have in getting onto the first rung of the housing "ladder", much less climbing it. Forgive me for noting that the British have plenty of problems of their own in that department, not least because of the lack of viable options for seniors wishing to downsize. It would seem that Britain doesn't have enough smaller homes into which those older people can move.

He hasn't won the election. The electoral college has not voted. I call on the electoral college to deprive Trump of 270 votes by casting their votes for other candidates. I voted for Hillary and believe she would be a fine president, but she is radioactive. If nobody gets 270 votes, the House picks the president. They should call upon Mitt Romney to serve. At this point I think he would be accepted by Democrats without hesitation. When you've stared into the face of the monster, a mere political opponent (and one with a history of being moderate before his campaign) is a yuuuge relief.

Moira, the will of the people suggests Hillary should be our President. There is no way around that.

We are the United States of America. Even Trump would agree that the last time we let the States put themselves before the Union ( in 2000 ), the result was "a disaster".

"The electoral college is a disaster for a democracy
This election is a total sham and a travesty. We are not a democracy!" - Donald J Trump
why should my vote count less than yours because I live in a highly populated state? One person, one vote.

Too many comments about the Electoral College reversing the result of the election.  That institution is now entI rely partisan.  Does no one realize the important work the Republican party did in securing state legislative districts, frequently by gerrymandering.  The representatives of the Electoral College wI'll mirror the results of a decade and more of Republican work at the local level.

We didn't elect Jared and Ivanka although an apparently unsure of himself Donald is allowing them to act as if they had been elected to the office.  Enough of Jared and Ivanka.  There record of family legal problems is deplorable.  Their gall in elbowing into the President's powers and judgments should be stopped or a weak Donald Trump should resign before Jared and Ivanka set him aside and take over directly or indirectly while he dithers and looks inept.

Bill-- my suspicion is that the kids are acutely aware of their father's serious mental and psychological weaknesses. There may even be a cognitive problem (i.e., early dementia). Remember, Trump was never forced to release his medical records. The children probably want to 'support' their father's decision making and cover his frailty. We cannot be so naive to believe this is not at least partly the case.
Bernie! We miss you
Well, that settles it. We can all give up, go home, and lock our doors now.
Joe, may I bring to your attention that you live in San Francisco?  Try Akron, Erie, Buffalo, Cleveland and new data may cause you to think differently.
what does this even mean?

@Staggerlee:
We like this America "in its primeval glory". You are welcome to join and enjoy it. You will be in the best country in the history of mankind.
But please, please....don't try to change it.
Bravo !

It should come as no surprise that Trump, who is a hothead and a bigot, is selecting a bunch of hotheaded bigots for key spots in his Administration. I would just add that it is a massive understatement to simply note that Trump's Attorney General nominee - Jefferson Beauregard Sessions III - has a "history of racially charged statements."

In fact, Sessions, who was named after the President of the Confederacy and a leading Confederate general, is an outright racist who has spent much of his career seeking to suppress voting by African Americans as much as possible. As U.S. Attorney, Sessions twice used bogus charges of voter fraud to unsuccessfully prosecute African Americans for working to register voters in the South. He has dismissed the Voting Rights Act as "intrusive," and celebrated when the Supreme Court significantly weakened it. He has done everything in his power to oppose efforts to end mass incarceration. And on immigration, Sessions not only wants to deport millions of people who have committed the misdemeanor of being in the US without documentation, and he wants to curb even entirely legal immigration.

In short, Sessions would bring to the Attorney General position a disturbing history of racist comments and behaviors that are not the types of characteristics we should want in the nation's top law enforcement officer. Democrats must vociferously and unanimously oppose this horrible nominee.

https://www.facebook.com/WinningProgressive

It will be especially interesting to see whether Sessions works to deport illegal immigrants from Europe as well as those from Mexico and the Americas. Irish newspapers regularly feature articles about illegal Irish immigrants in the US and speculate on whether the Irish immigrants will be deported.

This is just part of life? Have we all lost our minds?

Answer: yes ...

Bloody dangerous, encouraging lies and crazy hatreds.

Yes, I like that analogy. The train is already moving, moving quite fast. It can't be just stopped where it belongs anymore.

Things can be done, but they are not that the train stays back where it belonged.

And yes, it just keeps getting worse.

Not much of a metaphor. Find the eye in the hurricane? Easy; the only problem is that the eye moves and you have to move with it. And when nearly everyone else is exposed to the hurricane, isn't it going to get a just a little overcrowded?

The dance of that's going on is more complex than just "technology, globalization and Mother Nature". There are at least two other factors, labor and capital, and that's without considering population.

Quite simply, the hurricane of technology and robotics has so devalued the labor of so many people that it's bound to lead to instability. It has also biased the distribution of capital upwards. We have more billionaires, more at the low end of the ladder and relatively fewer at the middle rungs. It's all very well to tout services like Airbnb that we could theoretically sell to each other and sustain ourselves as individual capitalists, but it's very difficult to see how the math works out.

One given of today's world is that we restrict free movement of people but are ideologically fixated on free movement of capital - which is sold to the people as free trade. I wonder if some limitation on how capital moves might help reduce migration pressures. One adverse effect of trade deals has been to undermine indigenous food production in less developed counties, forcing people to migrate.

Thank you for this.  Everyone needs to be informed about the critical importance of the labor/capital relationship and how it affects our lives.  Piketty's book opened my eyes but I don't know anybody who has read it.

All such valid points...and also agree with Tom F that the rapid uptake with "acceleration" of computing power in the hand, the multiplier of FB that really started in 2010 (in mass U.S./actionable usage) and the negative implications that fragmented so many "large" demographic segments from the pre-1970's, to now, only communicating in work/play/social media...with their "like minded" friends...which obviates the point that our land of "milk and honey" is now more like Democratic almond milk with hard core Republication pesticide-ridden homogenized milk.

And Monsanto engineers sterile seeds, which it sells to rural farmers in India. They have no seed crop of their own and can be sued by Monsanto for trying to get around it. The result? Suicide by desperate people caught in a web of capitalism that destroys their ability to feed their family.

If we want peace and stability, we need to export the means to survive to people in poor regions, not exploit their vulnerability. It is capitalism's excesses that are killing us all. Expect to see it on steroids after January 20th.
What a disgusting, elitist, condescending letter. You are part of the problem of thinking how you are so much better than everyone else.
Are you implying that whites are the only people that work?

Sara,

The article is not insulting to me and I fit into two of these minority categories. There are also clear flaws in your logic and you are factually incorrect: having 11 or 12 million illegal immigrants (you use the political correct term 'migrants' ) move back to their own countries would raise wages for the worst off and poorest Americans. It is the law of supply and demand. While the KKK may have endorsed Trump, the Revolutionary Communist party endorsed Jill Stein -- both endorsements are meaningless and a weak red herring in your argument. Most offensive is that you assume that "white Christians" all have the same identify politics -- we don't. In your very phrasing you create "the other" and lower yourself down to the primitive school yard name calling you decry in others.
There is so much wrong with this, I don't quite know where to begin, but let me say this: it could ONLY have been written by a white man.

BDR,

Read Helena's comment again and ask yourself "What does Brexit, South Asia, and Tibet have to do with Sweden, Finland, and Singapore?"

So we should ignore that, as you delicately put it, "many Americans don't like the changing face of our country" and pretend it's not racism? We should stop talking about objectively measurable institutionalized racism because you're tired of hearing about it?

Is this why Trump won? Because white people can't stand anyone talking about anybody's problems but their own?

I notice these articles didn't appear BEFORE the election, in fact, there were many articles describing how the GOP would be at an disadvantage due to the changing nature of race in America.

The pendulum swings either way depending on the people you ask, either you are catering to the nth degree of diversity or enjoying a "whitelash" against it. In four years, it could another made up misnomer.

To me, it just sounds like finger pointing and sour grapes.

And I voted for Clinton!
Right. Everyone's a nitwit who did differently than you. Typical condescending liberal.

Honestly, publishing this on the same day Trump has named the anti-black racist Jeff Sessions as his AG pick is downright insulting. Black America did not go too far pushing for rights. White America never went far enough in recognizing those rights.

It's also a strong bit of navel-gazing to suggest that white people in Alabama and Wisconsin really care enough about what happens on campus at Columbia that they would make a reality TV host and casino conman into the world's most powerful person just to say "screw you" to an Ivy League Black Student Union. If there is someone who needs to look outside themselves as an urban elitist, it's Mr. Lilla.

I will add. I have lived in UK, Canada and now America. I am from a South American country bi birth but emigrated long time ago. In U.K. Nobody cares about you as an immigrant or your culture. In Canada they do care but have so little information about it. In American they want to care a lot but also THEY want to drive and lead the conversation.  Americans if you want to really advance this, let the own immigrants express themselves and LEAD the multicultural national conversation.  It's annoying when you just want to hog it.

Susan,

My comment had on this op-ed is about Trump. Your reply is off-topic. The entitled upper middle class owes the precariat (lower middle class, working class, the poor) an apology for not standing up for them and expecting them to vote against their interests as they fared better in this unequal economy. Kurt Eichenwald and his colleagues who have demonized the working class and minorities for not voting for the upper middle class and the .01%'s candidate can now go ask themselves how to unify the party before it disintegrates. They participated in a dangerous game of collusion in an attempt to sway public opinion through propaganda and games of divide and conquer. Not enough people bought into it and now we have Trump.

The myth the media spread is that only well-to-do right wing racists masquerading as working class would vote for Trump. It didn't quite turn out to work that way and it angered millions of lower middle and working class Democrats.

Who are those angry white voters? http://www.rimaregas.com/2016/06/profiling-the-angry-american-in-this-ne...

Were white voters the only ones who were angry? No!

You are not entitled to dictate for other people how to vote. You are not entitled to make up your own narrative. Keep up this attitude and you will have a class war on your hands.
